questions.text: What is the Value of INTERSTITIAL oncotic pressure ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 mm Hg Starling's hypothesis states that the fluid movement due to filtration across the wall of a capillary is dependent on the balance between the hydrostatic pressure gradient and the oncotic pressure gradient across the capillary .

Highyeild:

Increased capillary pressure failure of venous pumps, heart failure Decreased plasma protein osmotic pressure severe liver failure, nephrotic syndrome Increased capillary protein permeability due to release of vasoactive substances:- burns trauma infection

Extraedge:

The four Starling's forces are: hydrostatic pressure in the capillary (Pc) hydrostatic pressure in the interstitium (Pi) oncotic pressure in the capillary (pc ) oncotic pressure in the interstitium (pi ) The balance of these forces allows calculation of the net driving pressure for filtration. Net Driving Pressure=[( 𝑃𝑐 − 𝑃𝑖 )−( 𝑝𝑐 − 𝑝𝑖 )] Accumulation of fluid in interstitial space (due to filtration out of the capillaries) Usually caused by a disruption in Starling forces, that exceeds the ability of lymphatic system to return it to the circulation

Table:

#MANTRA Typical values of Starling Forces in Systemic Capillaries (mmHg) Arteriolar end of capillary Venous end of capillary Capillary hydrostatic pressure 25 10 Interstitial hydrostatic pressure -6 -6 Capillary oncotic pressure 25 25 Interstitial oncotic pressure 5 5

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure volume curve?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Functional residual capacity Functional residual capacity (FRC) , is the volume remaining in the lungs after a normal , passive exhalation. In a normal individual, this is about 3L . FRC = ERV + RV The FRC also represents the point of the breathing cycle where the lung tissue elastic recoil and chest wall outward expansion are balanced and equal.

Highyeild:

The FRC is important because: At FRC, the small airway resistance is low At FRC, lung compliance is maximal FRC maintains an oxygen reserve which maintain oxygenation between breaths At FRC , pulmonary vascular resistance is minima Where closing capacity is greater than the FRC , gas trapping and atelectasis can develop

Table:

#MANTRA Functional Residual Capacity = Volume of air in lungs after tidal expiration (RV + ERV). At this volume, the pulmonary system is in equilibrium because the collapsing force of the lungs is equal to the expanding force of the chest wall.

questions.text: Consider the following statements: Lead I-The positive electrode of ECG is connected to the right hand and negative to the left Lead II-The positive electrode is connected to the left hand and negative to the left leg Lead III- Negative electrode is connected to the left leg The grounding electrode is always connected to the right leg Select the correct answer from the below answer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only D Earthing to all leads is in the right leg is the correct statement

questions.text: Following image shows which of the following below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Babinski sign Plantar Reflex/Babinski Sign Root levels tested | L5 & S1 Pt position : Supine or seated Patient scrapes the end of a reflex hammer from the lateral heel of the foot up the lateral aspect of the foot and then across the metatarsal heads toward the hallux metatarsal head. Movement should take 5-6 seconds. Pt monitors for toe movement. Results Reflex PRESENT (adults) | digital flexion Reflex ABNORMAL (adults) | digital fanning pattern Abnormal plantar reflex is known as the Babinski sign and suggests an UMN lesion

questions.text: Patient with a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 came with 5 days of cough and high grade fever without chills and rigor. No history of diarrhea, vomiting, nuchal rigidity. Chest X ray is normal. What will you do?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Co-trimoxazole only The clinical scenario of an HIV-infected patient with a CD4 count of 200/mm with fever, cough , and a normal chest x-ray is indicative of underlying Pneumocystis pneumonia. Patients usually present with fever and non-productive cough. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver. The treatment of PCP is with cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). For patients with a Pa02 <70 mmH or with an arterial-alveolar (a-A) gradient >35 mHg. adjunct glucocorticoid therapy should be used in addition to cotrimoxazole . Alternative agents for the treatment of PCP. Atovaquone , pentamidine , and primaquine + clindamycin

Highyeild:

The classic radiographic appearance is likely normal or could consist of faint bilateral interstitial infiltrates . Perihilar infiltrates are less common in patients with AIDS . CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities. Histopathology of the tissue will show f oamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP

questions.text: Which among the following options shows Increase in high anion gap:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metabolic acidosis The anion gap is the difference between primary measured cations (sodium Na+ and potassium K+) and the primary measured anions (chloride Cl- and bicarbonate HCO3-) in serum. This test is most commonly performed in patients who present with altered mental status, unknown exposures, acute renal failure, and acute illnesses. The reference range for the anion gap is as follows: 16 ± 4 mEq/L (if the calculation employs potassium) 12 ± 4 mEq/L (if the calculation does not employ potassium) An elevated anion gap (>12 mEq/L; “mud pilers”) may indicate the following Methanol Uremia Diabetic ketoacidosis Propylene glycol Isoniazid intoxication Lactic acidosis Ethanol ethylene glycol Rhabdomyolysis/renal failure Salicylates

questions.text: A 45 year old lady becomes dyspneic in the whole process of going and coming from the washroom, what grade does she belong to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NYHA classification grade 3 NYHA Grading Class I No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation or dyspnoea. Class II Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation or dyspnoea. Class III Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest but less than ordinary activity results in fatigue, palpitation or dyspnoea. Class IV Unable to carry out any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort is increased. mMRC grading Screening tests Diagnostic tests Done on apparently healthy Done on those with indications for disease Applied to groups Applied to single patient Results arbitrary and final Diagnosis is not final Based on one criteria or cutoff point Based on number of findings Less accurate More accurate Less expensive More expensive Not basis for treatment Used as a basis for treatment Initiation comes from the investigator Initiation comes from a patient Screening test Diagnostic test 1 Done on apparently healthy Done on those with indications or sick. 2 Applied to groups Applied to single patients, all diseases are considered. 3 Test results are arbitrary and final Diagnosis is not final but modified in light of new evidence, diagnosis is the sum of all evidence. 4 Based on one criterion or cut-off point Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs (e.g., diabetes) and laboratory findings. 5 Less accurate More accurate. 6 Less expensive More expensive. 7 Not a basis for treatment Used as a basis for treatment. 8 The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care. The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint. Grade Dyspnea related to activity 1 Breathlessness only on strenuous exercise 2 Breathless when hurrying on the level or walking up a slight hill 3 Walks slower than other people of same age on the level due to shortness of breath or need to stop for breath when walking at own pace 4 Short of breath after walking few minutes on the level or about 100 yards (90m) 5 Too breathless to leave the house, or breathless when dressing or undressing Modified from The Medical Research Council Dyspnea scale (mMRC dyspnea scale)

questions.text: Cardiogenic shock has the following features:

options.label: A
options.text: Cardiac output decreases & Heart rate increases

options.label: B
options.text: Cardiac output decreases and heart rate decreases

options.label: C
options.text: Cardiac output increases and heart rate decreases

options.label: D
options.text: Both cardiac output and heart rate decreases

questions.correct_answer: A. Cardiac output decreases & Heart rate increases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiac output decreases & Heart rate increases Cardiogenic shock There is usually a history of an elderly person with a known cardiac ailment now presenting with symptoms attributable to cardiac pathology. Usually signs of cold clammy skin and feeble pulse → low cardiac output Above features with Hypotension Tachycardia Raised JVP → Cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock is characterized by reduced oxygen delivery related to a reduction in CO owing to a primary cardiac problem. There is usually a compensatory increase in SVR in cardiogenic shock. Hence cardiac output decreases and as a compensation, heart rate increases . Distributive shock is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the physiologic disturbance is a) Reduction in SVR ( Primary disturbance) b) Compensatory increase in cardiac output c) Fall in CVP and PCWP (Pulmonary capillary wedge pressures Obstructive shock - Characterized by a) Reduction in oxygen delivery related to reduced CO (Cardiac output) b) Etiology of the reduced CO is an extra-cardiac processes impairing blood flow Hypovolemic shock encompasses disease processes that reduce CO (and oxygen delivery) via a reduction in preload characterised by Cold skin Feeble pulse Tachycardia Tachypnoea Elevated SVR Low JVP / Low CVP Improving on IV fluids

Highyeild:

Hypovolemic shock Cardiogenic shock Obstructive shock Warm septic shock Cold septic shock (same as cardiogenic shock) CO ↓ ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓ HR ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↓ SVR ↑ ↑ ↑ ↓ ↑ EF ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ PCWP & JVP ↓ ↑ ↓ N/↓ ↑ BP/MVP ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ Base deficit ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ Skin temp. ↓ ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓

questions.text: Following conditions is not seen in optic disc in glaucoma except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roenne’s Nasal Step Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma. Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field. Glaucomatous changes Vertically oval cup Large cup (C:D ratio > 0.6) Asymmetry of cups (Difference of C:D ratio > 0.2) Atrophy of NRR Pallor areas of disc Splinter haemorrhages Bayonetting sign: double angulation of blood vessels Baring of circumlinear blood vessels Laminar dot sign: Slit like pores of lamina cribrosa is visible Marked cupping: Cup to disc ratio > 0.7 to 0.9 Nasal shifting of blood vessels NRR thinning (Crescentic shadow adjacent to disc margin) Optic atrophy: This is the end stage where all NRR are destroyed, Optic Nerve Head (ONH) appears white and is deeply excavated Pulsation of retinal arterioles at disc margin

questions.text: Identify the abnormality in the following ECG. [Identification of second degree heart block on ECG. A 72 year old man during his annual health check-up found the following ECG finding, it is a case of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2nd degree Heart Block First-degree heart block : The electrical impulse still reaches the ventricles, but moves more slowly than normal through the AV node. The impulses are delayed. This is the mildest type of heart block. Second-degree heart block is classified into two categories: Type I and Type II. In second-degree heart block, the impulses are intermittently blocked. Type I, also called Mobitz Type I or Wenckebach’s AV block: This is a less serious form of second-degree heart block. The electrical signal gets slower and slower until your heart actually skips a beat. Type II, also called Mobitz Type II: While most of the electrical signals reach the ventricles every so often, some do not and your heartbeat becomes irregular and slower than normal. Third-degree heart block: The electrical signal from the atria to the ventricles is completely blocked. Third-degree block seriously affects the heart’s ability to pump blood out to your body.

Highyeild:

Treatment:- MEDS ATROPINE EPINEPHRINE NITROGLYCERIN IV Infusion Dopamine TEMPORARY PACER Permanent Pacer WIRES ARE INSERTED INTO THE HEART VIA THE VEINS AND ATTACHED TO A PULSE GENERATOR (THE PACEMAKER). THE PACEMAKER HAS A BATTERY INSIDE PACEMAKER IMPLANTATION - A SMALL DEVICE CAN BE FELT UNDER THE SKIN

Extraedge:

Heart Block occur when the conduction of impulses through the AV nodal area is decreased or stopped. Causes of Heart Block:- Drugs (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, amiodarone) Cardiomyopathy rheumatic fever, myocarditis varicella-zoster virus infection Rheumatic diseases Hypoxia Hyperkalemia Hypothyroidism inferior wall myocardial infarction

questions.text: In hypothyroidism following values is altered:

options.label: A
options.text: TSH Increase and T3, T4 Decrease

options.label: B
options.text: TSH Normal and T4, T3 Low

questions.correct_answer: A. TSH Increase and T3, T4 Decrease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TSH Increase and T3, T4 Decrease Elevated TSH with a low level of free T4 is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. Patients with hypothyroidism often present with:- tiredness, weakness, dry skin, hair loss, difficulty in concentrating, poor memory, constipation, and weight gain with poor appetite. On examination , they may have:- cool peripheral extremities, puffy faces, bradycardia, and peripheral edema. Patients with hypothyroidism who have no evidence of heart disease are managed with levothyroxine 50 to 100 mcg daily. The goal of the treatment is to maintain TSH in the lower half of the reference range. questions.text: SARs Covid can be detected by all except:

options.label: B
options.text: Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Southern Blotting Southern blotting is a laboratory technique used to detect a specific DNA sequence in a blood or tissue sample. Covid is an RNA virus Diagnostic modality in Covid Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is a laboratory technique combining reverse transcription of RNA into DNA (in this context called complementary DNA or cDNA) and amplification of specific DNA targets using polymerase chain reaction (PCR Rapid antigen tests target the SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein, the most abundant protein expressed by the virus ELISA is performed on 96-well plates coated with either SARS-CoV-2 recombinant RBD or spike proteins. Anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgM Spike Protein ELISA is intended for qualitative screening of IgM

questions.text: Patient on Tab. Losartan, for 3 years and now has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus, with HbA1C 8. What drug should be given instead of losartan?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Telmisartan ACE inhibitors or ARBs are the first-line treatment of choice for hypertension in a diabetic patient. They reduce proteinuria and delay diabetic nephropathy. Telmisartan also has PPAR-gamma agonist action. It is very useful in hypertensive patients with diabetes. Basically losartan can be given in type 2 DM. But telmisartan is more effective in reducing proteinuria.

Solution:

Adipose Tissue Glucose uptake by skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues is via GLUT-4 which is insulin-dependent. In the presence of insulin, GLUT-4 receptors translocate to the cell membrane and hence, glucose uptake by the cell occurs. Solution:

Vitamin B6 uncommon heritable and acquired erythropoietic disorders that are due to various abnormalities in heme synthesis and mitochondrial function. Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia that results from abnormal utilization of iron during erythropoiesis . There are different forms of sideroblastic anemia, and all forms are defined by the presence of ring sideroblasts in the bone marrow . Ring sideroblasts are erythroid precursors containing deposits of non-heme iron in mitochondria forming a ring-like distribution around the nucleus. The iron-formed ring covers at least one-third of the nucleus rim. Sideroblastic anemia is known to cause microcytic and macrocytic anemia depending on what type of mutation led to it. Unlike iron deficiency anemia, where there is depletion of iron stores, patients with sideroblastic anemia have normal to high iron level The management of sideroblastic anemia depends on severity. For patients diagnosed with the X-linked sideroblastic anemia, oral pyridoxine 50-100mg/day has been proven to partially or completely correct anemia . For patients who are not responsive to pyridoxine, blood transfusion is indicated if they have severe anemia

questions.text: Most specific Cardiac marker within 2 hrs:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CKMB The criteria for AMI require a rise and/or fall in cardiac biomarker values with at least one value above the 99th percentile of the upper reference limit for normal individuals. Cardiac-specific troponin T (cTnT) and cardiac-specific troponin I (cTnI) are now the preferred biochemical markers for MI The cardiac troponins are of particular value in distinguishing UA from NSTEMI Levels of cTnI and cTnT may remain elevated for 7–10 days after STEMI. CK-MB2 can be detected in serum within 2-4 hours after infarction onset and peaks at 6-9 hours, making it an early marker for acute MI However, cardiac surgery, myocarditis, and electrical cardioversion often result in elevated serum levels of the MB isoenzyme. A ratio (relative index) of CK-MB mass to CK activity ≥2.5 suggests but is not diagnostic of a myocardial rather than a skeletal muscle source for the CK-MB elevation.

Highyeild:

Diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) The criteria to label AMI are: Typical increase and gradual decrease in Cardiac Troponin-T Rapid rise in CK-MB and its fall Ischemic changes leading to symptoms ECG shows pathological Q-wave ECG shows ST-segment elevation or depression Coronary angiography will confirm the diagnosis. Outcome of AMI pathological changes

Extraedge:

Requires presence of at least two of the following characteristics: Typical heart attack symptoms Characteristic rise and fall pattern of a cardiac marker in plasma: Rise and gradual fall of cardiac troponins More rapid rise and fall of CK-MB Typical ECG pattern
